title: How I Love Myself Through a Depressive Episode

content: There’s a monster that sits behind me, its looming shadow creeping over my shoulder. It whispers in my ear, the same things over and over, on a hamster wheel, an endless loop.
It shoves me with shame and drowns me in guilt. Am I the things it tells me? Am I lazy and unlovable? A failure? Broken and incapable?

I wish I had a better answer to how I love myself through a depressive episode, but the truth is, I don’t. Self-compassion is one of the hardest things for me to practice, especially in the midst of a depression that crumbles my self-esteem and guilt-trips me into believing things that aren’t true. Loving myself gets pushed to the back corner of my mind, and I can’t fathom extending grace to myself. To others? Always. But I set myself to a higher, impossible standard, an expectation I will never actually reach. Somewhere so high in the sky, I can’t even see it.

content: When a bit of the depression cloud clears, I find small ways to extend acts of self-love to myself. I think loving yourself isn’t always about manifestations of confidence or looking in the mirror and admiring what you see. It’s in the acts of self-care and connection you can build on.

I love myself in subtle ways – hot showers and a Starbucks coffee on a rough day. Making plans with friends and reaching out for help when I need it. Each of these actions reinforces the belief that I am deserving of self-love, even if it doesn’t feel like it. Even when my depression tells me I’m not worthy.

The community that surrounds me loves me wholly, and I’m so grateful for it. They offer me love when I cannot offer it to myself. Through being vulnerable and connecting with loved ones, I perform another act of self-love.

I’ve come to realize that even if it's incrementally, I’m learning to love myself a bit more each year of my life. I’m learning new ways to take care of myself so that the next time depression bullies me and overwhelms me, I’m more confident in my resiliency and who I am apart from it.

content: I am not my depression. And that is something I’m still learning to accept. It’s the thought that is so hard to truly believe when it feels like the pieces that make me who I am are dissolving to make room for depression. Depression tells me I am nothing but darkness, like the person I really am doesn’t deserve to be here. It crushes my self-confidence and destroys my self-esteem and perception of myself. I go one step forward and three steps back.
I feel as though I should be able to control my illness. I feel as though I am failing myself.

It is not my fault. It is not my fault. It is not my fault. I am so many things that are not my depression. I am so beautiful and capable, resilient, and smart. I’m a good friend and a talented person. I’m compassionate and loving.
Loving. Loving. Loving. To myself, maybe not today. But maybe tomorrow.
